 I've just been studying the figures in the BBC World Service Poll (for which you gave a link). 
 
 The numbers for Britain are "only" 64% negative, 29% postive (slightly above average negativity for all the countries in the list). I say "only" because I'm a bit surprised that Mr Bush gets nearly a one third approval rating among the British people who were asked for their opinion - and for this reason. There are about 10 national newspapers published in Britain and only ONE of them ever editorialises in Bush's favor. All of the TV channels are united in their strong disapproval of President Bush and everything he stands for.
 
 Most people seem to acquire their political opinions from the "hidden agenda" pursued by the press and television, and only a few people have the rational disposition and confidence in their own judgement that will enable them to question the received wisdom. On this basis, I'm surprised that 29% have been recorded as reaching independent conclusions - perhaps having resisted the trend of majority opinion. That doesn't mean to say that I think the 29% are necessarily "right". But I'm pleased that a significant number of British people do not appear to be gripped by unreflecting anti-Americanism despite Bush's obvious limitations as a politician and miscalculations in Iraq and elsewhere.
